advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US BROCHURE (VERSO)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Chris Collman for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> M-SERIES BROCHURE - PAGE 5</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from Byte magazine (january 1977) said : <br><br> ...It gets its speed and power from a selected version of the new Z80 microprocessor that can operate at a 4 Mhz. clock rate (The Z-1 also lets you switch to 2 Mhz. to be compatible with older systems)...<br> ...The Z-1 offers you all kinds of peripherals and softwares. It uses the standard ''S100'' bus supported by over a dozen manufacturers. And all Cromemco peripherals (PROM memory and programmer, Ram memory, analog I/O, color TV interface, etc) just plug into the Z1's sockets...<br> ... The Z-1 comes completely assembled ans tested. It's a quality, commercial grade microcomputer. It is not available as a kit.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SEMI-TECH BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT.</strong></font><br><blockquote>The YIS-503 is a YIS-303 with more memory (32 kb) and a proper keyboard.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, APRIL 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, April 1982<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST ADVERT - JAN.1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This guy has so much power in his hands that he has attracted two girls (so far) in his swimming-pool ! <br><br> Notice the classical symbol of the 80s adverts : the glass of orange juice with a straw...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> DUTCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Richard de Keijzer</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a German advertisement for the BIT-60 and BIT-90 models. Atari VCS-2600 cartridges are scattered in front of the BIT-60 to show that the it is really compatible with the VCS-2600 ! But strangely enough, there is no picture displayed on the TV. Were these models really working ? ;-)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COCO CLONE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sampo, a Taiwanese company specialized in monitors and video terminals production also attempted to produce a CoCo clone computer, but the marketing little lasted. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> SPANISH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983 </strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably the last advert made by T.I. in the UK</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a small advert from a french reseller "Vectron". The ad is dated november 1984 and the EXL-100 is sold for 3240fr. <br><br> The title says : "The french answer" </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> INTERACTION NEWSLETTER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Three issues of this 'Newsletter Detroit Interact Group' were published during the first semester of 1980</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Gazelle was a huge computer compared to the personal computer sizes of the time, so large that it has casters on the cabinet for moving it!</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR BROCHURE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>NorthStar brochure - Page 2 <b>EXPANSION OPTIONS</b><br><br> <b>HRAM.64</b> - High Speed 64Kb Dynamic RAM memory board with parity (up to a total of six)<br> <b>HSIO.4</b> - Four Serial Port Expansion Board (RS-232C or Current Loop).<br> <b>FPB</b> - Floating Point Arithmetic Board.<br> <b>ADC-2D</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Double capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (360 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>ADC-2Q</b> - Two additionaI 5 1/4 inch Quad capacity floppy disk drives incorporated within a cabinet (720 Kb total capacity).<br> <b>HDS-5</b> - 5 1/4 inch Winchester Hard Disk 5 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>HDS-18</b> - 14 inch Winchester Hard Disk 18 Mb formatted capacity.<br> <b>Tape Backup</b> - 13.4 Mb Tape Backup system for HDS-18 or HDS-5.<br> <b>CRT</b> - Hazeltine 1420/Soroc 120. (Other software drivers available.)<br> <b>Printer</b> - 35 or 55 cps letter quality printer. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Gordon Dyer</b> from England </p></blockquote>

computer.cpu: None. Chipsets are located in each cartridge
computer.description:
This is a typical system using catridges based on the different chipsets developped by General Instruments in the late 70s. Each GI chips was able to generate several games, ball games for a start, then later car racing, motorcycle, submarines, tanks and shooting games.
The system has two detachable controllers with one analog joystick and one fire button each. The control panel is composed of 10 buttons to select the different games offered by each cartridge (10 being the maximum). Difficulty switches, power switch, service auto/manual switch and a start button can also be found.
Hopefully there's even a volume control slider, which is VERY useful as the sound coming of this console is quite irritating.
This particular model was apparently designed by Soundic in Hong-Kong and then sold to many companies worldwide so they could market the system under their own brand. That's why the SD-070 console can be found under many different brands. Case design may vary but inside it is always the same motherboard. The electronic board of the one we have opened is labeled "SD-70S Rev. 4", S surely stands for SECAM (we had a french model). There were also SD-050 and SD-090 models, all compatible with each others, i.e. using PC-50x cartridges.
computer.keyboard: Two controllers with analog joysticks and a fire button.
computer.name: SD 070 Colour (programmable TV-game console)
computer.ports: Power in, TV RF video output, 2 x controller connectors, lightgun connector
computer.power: External power supply unit, DC 9v, 200 mA + -(o- -or 6 x 1.5V UM-2 batteries
